This helps to ensure the Fleet disk jockey complete artistic control. The station's listenership crosses through traditional Auckland demographics reaching a diverse audience particularly those involved in the Arts and creative industries.Fleet has held a variety of music and art related events, such as the infamous 'Convoy' gigs and Camp Fleet, when on New Years the radio station takes over a classic Kiwi school camp. nz.description: Nestled in the heart of Kaitaia is SUNSHINE 104.3 FM, a busy local radio station that serves the Far North of New Zealand and covers from north of Mangamuka to Cape Reinga, and across to Mangonui on the east coast. Sunshine FM have a friendly, professional and commercial approach to broadcasting. Since first going to air in February 1998, we have received great support from the local business community, local service clubs, emergency services and of course our listeners. The audience ranges in age from about 30 to 50 years or anyone who likes ‘Classic Hits from the 60’s to today’. Broadcasting goes 24 hours, Monday to Sunday, with News, sport and weather provided every hour on the hour. Sunshine also promotes Māori language and customs to the wider community, and this adds a significant cultural dynamic to our product. The advertising content has a community specific focus. How can you can be involved? You are welcome to participate or send us feedback about any of our music, promotions or events. If you’re keen to be on the radio, please get in touch as we’re always looking for volunteers to be part of our vibrant team.

nz.name: Te Hiku Radio
nz.description: Te Hiku 97.1 FM is part of the iwi communities of Te Hiku o Te Ika/the Far North, and belongs collectively to it’s five iwi. Te Hiku FM and was born out of the dreams and aspirations of our kuia and kaumātua (elders), as a way to retain Māori language communication within our whānau, hapu and iwi. The iwi radio format is packed with local news, interactive talkback and Waiata in Te Reo Māori. The station promotes the use of Te Reo Māori as a means of everyday communication, and whilst targeted at native speakers, listening to the station is a great way to improve Te Reo Māori for beginners, and second language learners. How do you get involved? Te Hiku FM is always keen to hear your views and encourages listeners to contribute to topical discussion. If you have a panui to share with the iwi or a kaupapa that you would like to talk about then please contact Maria Tauroa.
